Note : I switched back to a full jug before observing the first arrival , and that chickadee did n't produce enough movement to spill any water . During weeks 3 and 4 , only the larger adult chickadee used the waterer -- the smaller adult ( mate ? ) who feeds second continued to drink from the nearby ant-trap even though it was in a somewhat more exposed location ( there are Cooper 's Hawks , so they switch off on look-out duties ) . At the beginning of week 5 , the juvenile chickadees started showing up at the feeder and they quickly adopted the waterer and the smaller adult started using it as well.My suspicion is that the perch is just too close to the water jug for even small birds to land comfortably . The adult chickadees that I have seen using it land not head-in , but vertically or sideways on the perch , appearing to also use a connector bar ( between the perching circle and the tray ) . The adult chickadees also drink predominantly sideways -- they duck down and turns their heads sideways to get at the tray . The juvenile chickadees are small enough to drink head-on.This observation screams that the tray-perch is much too small relative to the jug. -- -- Cleaning : questionable adviceThe typical advice for cleaning hummingbird feeders is to use vinegar and to avoid soap . Some claim that hummingbirds hate soap 's taste , other that it causes problems with their digestive system ( or they may hate the taste because of those problems ) .Consequently , I was surprised that the advice was to clean with mild soap . Soap and vinegar have very different roles . Detergents such a soaps are molecules that have one end that binds to water and the other to a oil or grease molecule and thus allows water flow to pull off not just that oil/grease but everything else that is attached to it . Vinegar is a weak acid that tears apart or dissolves other types of contaminants . This is why you will find both in many cleaning products . My understanding of the types of problems likely to occur -- minerals and harmful biologics -- are ones dealt with by vinegar and on which soap has little/no effect . There is no mention of bleach ( either way ) . -- -- Apparent theory of operation ( beyond the basics ) : The slots that release the water into the tray are very thin . When I first turned over the feeder , the water released did n't even completely cover the bottom . But rock the feeder even slightly -- as it would in the wind or from birds landing -- and more water is released . This has the potential to do more than just replenish the water in the tray -- the currents _might_ help float debris up and over the sides . I could simulate a little of this by hitting the perch with my finger , but it would take actual birds landing to confirm this speculation.Observation from current use : With evaporation and without periodic rocking , the water in the tray can become very depleted -- not completely covering the bottom -- which might then not provide sufficient attraction for birds to land and providing the rocking to do the replenishment.Suggestion : One might want to periodically give this product a tap to release a bit more water into the tray. -- Douglas B. Moran

When it comes to birding , cleanliness is very important . With the jug handle , this waterer is hard to clean , even with a flexible brush . I have lots of finches , and with finches , comes conjunctivitis , and being able to clean this properly is very important . Sure , I could just slosh some bleach around it when cleaning , but I 'm not comfortable not being able to scrub each and every inch of this . If it has been one solid jug , it would 've been much easier to clean.I 've had it up for a few weeks now and have not noticed one bird on it . Only small birds can use this , which I have plenty of ( sparrows , finches , chickadees , nuthatches , etc ) . Initially I did put it up a few feet away from a thistle feeder , and the goldfinches abandoned the feeder . Once I moved this waterer , the birds came back . Strange , but not unheard of . It 's now near the bird bath and still , no takers .

My Perky Pet Water cooler is too small for all but the smallest of birds to sit on the ledge while drinking . There is no stabilization so it swings back and forth as soon as a bird does land on it , consequently the bird flies off because it 's swinging . You have to take it completely down to fill and then screw off the bottom which is where the birds poop is . I would n't recommend this product just because you have to get it down from the tree , and then touch bird excrement and then the birds do n't use it anyway because it sways and is just too small . Mine did not come with a hook to hang it so you 'll have to find your own S hook or string to hand it with .

I live in an extremely dry area , so I would think that the birds I feed would welcome water . After over a week , though , I have yet to see any evidence that they are getting a benefit from this . I recognize two parts of the problem but not the full problem.To begin with , the hook on the top of the container will not fit over many hooks or nails , so I had to use some nylon line to hang the waterer . If you buy one , there is a plastic tie that holds on the tag and instructions ( if these can be called instructions ) , and I recommend you do n't cut it off as I did . That little tie should be enough.Filling the plastic bottle with water was easy enough , and attaching the base was easy , too . But that 's when I noticed the first problem . Very little water actually came out . The next day , when I went to check , the dish from which the birds are supposed to drink was bone dry . So I shook the bottle a bit and induced some water into the dish . The next day , the dish was dry again . Once again , I jiggled the bottle and managed to get a little bit of water into the dish.I 've tried screwing the base on more tightly and doing so more loosely , but water simply does not seem to want to leave the bottle and settle in the dish . That 's the first part of the problem.The second part is that the base seems just too small for many birds . In the time I have had this , I must have looked at it forty or fifty times . There have been birds galore on the feeder two feet to the right of the water bottle but never a bird on the water tray.I gave it two stars rather than one in deference to those who love it . Perhaps my bottle is just defective in some way . But , having disassembled it and inspected it ( thinking perhaps that the plastic had n't been cut back sufficiently where the water was supposed to come out -- not the problem , I discovered ) , I can not recommend this product .

I 've had this up for a couple weeks now and have yet to see any birds on it . The problem seems to be that the perches are quite small and there is n't a lot of drinking space ; the design requires that the bird sort of duck under the jug . We 'll see what we 'll see , but so far this has been a bust for me - on my wooded property most avian visitors are woodpecker or cardinal -size birds - this seems designed for small finches.The design of the thing is pretty clever , but you WILL lose some water when turning it upside-down . Once upright the water wicks out somehow - provided you screwed the jug in fully.It 's pretty small . Maybe if you are trying to encourage sparrows and drive pigeons away it would be good ?

Before I start my review let me give you an overview of the environment : We have a decently large size backyard with lots of trees and shrubs . We never really needed to attract birds as they love our backyard anyways due to the peace and serenity we tend keep in the backyard . we also do not have a dog or small child to scare the birds away . We generally sit by the patio on pleasant evenings and watch birds with ease as they keep chirping , digging for worms and or merely having fun . Over the years we have seen certain species of birds ( we call them the 'usual ' suspects ) who are not scared of us anymore and go about doing their business chasing each other or just like to dig for worms from the backyard lawn.When Amazon offered me this Perky-Pet Water Cooler Bird Waterer for review I gladly accepted to review it thinking that we will be able to watch these birds drink water from time to time and moreover as summer is around the corner we will be able to provide some thirst relief to the birds in our backyard.The product received for review is cute and well constructed - there is no doubt in that . It Looks good , functions and obeys laws of physics and drips water automatically as designed but sadly does not attract birds of any kinds as of yet . It has been nearly a week and I have not seen a single bird ever drink water from it . They zoom fly past by it never even looking at it once.I personally think the problem is with the base . The base in my opinion is too small for the types of birds in our backyard to land on and drink water thereby avoiding it completely . I am reading other reviewers who have had some degree of success with it . It is possible that those who have had success might be due to small birds in their backyard.Anyways , as the product did not attract birds as expected I am currently rating it with 2 stars . Attractive to humans but not birds is my feedback with the original design . I have plans to make the base a bit wider by attaching a plastic plate underneath the waterer and hang it in the same tree . I will update my review with my findings . Please see the comments section with in next couple of weeks or so with my updated results .

Really awful design.The product works on the principle of suction , so be careful when flipping it over to hang . I spilled water all over my kitchen and myself ! It does not come with any hanging equipment , so be sure to purchase that if you get this product.I think the perky pet people forgot that this product hangs outside and is frequently going to be pooped on by birds . The water bottle top and the blue water dish below screw on and off . The water bottle top needs to be turned right side up to fill . It can not be filled while still hanging on the tree.I do not wish to handle a poop laden water cooler every time this product needs refilling.Also , I tried to cut a hole in the bottom of the water bottle so I could fill it with water from the top . DO NOT do this , the whole thing works on the principle of suction , and once it has a hole in the bottom it wo n't work anymore.Anyway , the plastic seems like good quality because it took a lot of effort for me to cut a hole through it . The water dish is of less solid construction.All in all , I would not recommend this product at all.Update : I filled it up with birdseed , but unless you have very tiny granules of seed , it wo n't work . The seed just gets stuck and you have to empty it by unscrewing it . ( Which defeats the purpose of cutting a hole in it ) .

I was quite excited about it at first when this bird waterer first came out . Unfortuatly , it does n't work too well . First , the device should come with an axilliary hook for hanging it . If you have a rigid pole with a firm hook at its end , it would be much more convenient to hang this had it came with a hook to go between the waterer and the pole . That way you can hang it without turning it sideway to fit it onto the pole . The device is not too attractive and looks just like what it is , an ugly plastic jug . The dish on the bottom surrounding the water container is too narrow for birds to have enough of a ledge to land on and to stand up in order to start drinking . The space is just too tight for anything but the smallest of birds . Lastly , water does not run out of the jug nicely to fill the dish on the bottom unless aided by a little shaking which is an absurdly inconvenient thing to have to do . This device has too many problems to work well .

This feeder is even prettier in person . The color is deeper red than it looked to me in the picture and it is beautiful when the sun hits it.The only thing keeping this from being a perfect feeder for me is there is n't a perch and I love to watchthe hummingbirds sit and look around . But I keep a feeder out with a perch too so I have the best of both worlds in observing them.Very pretty design in the glass too . Assembled in the USA of Chinese Parts . *Update* I decided to take it down and put up a different one . This is such a pretty feeder , but it 's not practical . Also , after a month of use the red has started chipping off already . Cleaning the base is simple , but the inside glass gets slimy and the mouth of the bottle is so narrow that I ca n't get anything in there to clean it out . I shake soap and water in it , but it still has some slime .

This feeder holds just the right amount of nectar but after a few refills it began leaking . Eight ounces is a good quantity for the birds to consume before the feeder should be washed out and refilled with fresh fluid . When we first used it we were impressed with its superior functionality . It 's also attractive to have hanging outside a window . Unfortunately , even though we gave it gentle handling and good care , it began to leak and ultimately became useless .

I 've had many hummingbird feeders , but this is the first one that opens from the top . It is so much easier to fill , I did n't even need a funnel . And cleaning the glass jar is so much easier also . And if I 'm going to be gone for a few days , I can top the nectar off . I like the ant moat on top also , as I do have that problem . I wish it was a little deeper though , as I think it will dry up very fast on hot days . I do n't know if this feeder comes in a larger size , but if it does , I would like one . I feed a lot of hummers ! By the way , you do n't need artificially colored purchased nectar . Just boil 4 parts water and one part sugar for a couple of minutes , and let it cool.Well , sadly I 'm only giving this 2 stars now instead of 5 . Why ? Because the hummers do n't like it . It 's not because it does n't have a base . My other glass feeder does n't either , and they love my old one . I have this one hanging in a small oak tree , so the have lots of places to sit after eating . So I think it must be the rubbery flowers . maybe I can switch the flowers from my other old perky pet feeder .

PLEASE NOTE ADDITION TO REVIEW BELOW.I *love* this hummingbird feeder ! ! ! I have two others , both your standard cheap feeder that is so difficult to fill because of a small opening , and once filled , you have to flip it upside down and it notoriously drips across my deck , inviting ants to the sugar syrup . This Perky-Pet 24 ounce Glass feeder , however , fills from a VERY large top opening ! It also has an `` ant moat '' on the top which you can fill with water so your feeder is n't crawling with sugar-seeking ants . What a great idea ! Another plus is that this feeder holds a full 24 ounces of food , while the smaller cheaper units hold only 8 ounces . My birds will be so happy ! Just an FYI . Do you know you can make your own hummingbird food for your feeder ? You do n't need to buy the expensive packets that include red food coloring , which the birds do n't need . Simply boil 4 cups of water in a pan , add 1 cup of sugar , stir until sugar is dissolved , and boil gently for 2 more minutes . Let it cool and put in your feeder . My birds love this food and there is no reason to have to add any red coloring.I highly , highly recommend this Perky-Pet Hummingbird Feeder . Another FYI . When you take the feeder out of the box , you 'll think it comes with no hook to hang it with , but look under the top lid and you 'll find it.My hummingbirds are so happy ! ADDED 08/10/13 : I return to revise this review . After 2 weeks of using the hummingbird feeder , it started to leak around the base near the flower feeders . This base comes apart for cleaning , but there is no gasket of any kind to create a water tight seal . Once I took it apart to clean , it never sealed properly again . My husband even used an epoxy glue around the base in an effort to seal it , but that did n't work . I ended up having to throw the feeder away ! ! ! So fair warning -- this feeder looks good , has great potential , but since it wo n't hold the liquid for more than 24 hours it 's actually quite useless .

This is a revision of a previously posted review . I had to bump my rating down to 1 star.We very occasionally get hummingbirds in our yard , and I do have a feeder , as well as `` hummingbird-friendly '' plants . Because people in the area have been seeing more of these winged jewels , and because the rufous hummingbird is said to be expanding its range into the Midwest , I am trying to do everything possible to lure these little beauties into our yard.Perky Pet makes bird feeders that are reliable ( based on my previous Amazon Vine selections ) , so when this came up on the catalog , I requested it right away . ( Also , our local bird authorities at Wild Bird store highly rate the brand on many levels . ) It 's an attractive item . The red should draw in the hummingbirds , and the feeding ports are soft rubber flowers that appear very accessible to the bird . There 's an ant moat at the top of the feeder , a little trough that you fill with water to drown invading ants , and so keep the bird stations clear of insects . Assembly for filling , and cleaning , is simple.The feeder is fairly large . Because Chicago gets few hummingbirds compared to other parts of the country , a full feeder would last a year even if you have a steady stream of visitors . If you live in Texas and your garden is the center of hummingbird activity in your area , maybe that 's practical . But a 24 oz feeder is a little too big . The temptation to fill it up and then wait until it 's half empty means that stale nectar will just sit in the feeder , attracting nothing besides suicidal ants.Initially I thought there was no hanger included . Then another reviewer ( see below ) pointed out to me that the hanger is taped inside the lid ... which I had not noticed , even though I had to remove the lid to fill the hanger . So I went out to check , and sure enough , there it was -- -but it 's really inadequate . It 's just a little S-hanger , like you get with your dog 's rabies tag . So , we still had to make one . We used one of those fake caribiners.The other Perky Pet feeders we received did have hangers attached.We 've had it up for a few months now , and have yet to see a hummingbird . That 's okay , because I know they 're in the area . I think they 'll discover our yard next year when our various trumpet vines mature and we get a jump on the season.But they wo n't be coming for this particular feeder ... we had to throw it out . The seam where the glass meets the base started leaking . We considered attempting a repair with epoxy , but I do n't know if that would have introduced toxins into the materials . So we cut our losses and removed the feeder entirely . We still have another feeder out there , and we 'll probably replace the Perky Pet with another feeder similar to the one that has remained intact .

I unboxed this chipper and thought it looked pretty nice for the money . I fired it up and chipped a few very small pine twigs to start . So far , so good . Then I started to feed 1/2 '' to 3/4 '' pine branches in and within a minute the machine started to vibrate like it was going to fall apart . I opened the cover and there was nothing lodged or inside at all but the machine continued to vibrate.I contacted the manufacturer who promptly replied that they 'd be sending me a replacement . Wow - I was impressed that they were serious about taking care of their customers . Except that ... that was all talk ! That offer came 21 days ago , and guess what - no replacement . Emails back and forth from them explain that they 're upgrading systems and ca n't ship anything until their systems are upgraded . HUH ? 3 weeks of not shipping anything ? Walk it to the post office then . Do something ! Do n't just tell me your systems are down for the better part of a month and you ca n't do anything about it ; that 's ridiculous . As of today they do n't even respond to inquiries as to what the status of my replacement is . I 'm very carefully watching the days so that I do n't end up getting stuck with this thing because of Amazon 's 30 day return policy . My biggest concern is that I threw away the box when they emailed me informing me that they 'll be sending a new one with a box to return the old one in.I 've been using the unit despite the vibration , and it just does n't perform well . Sometimes it shoots out entire branches ( especially rose branches that are fresh ) . They 're dinged up , but intact - not chipped . If you try anything over 3/4 '' you 're just going to be frustrated and disappointed . The machine will take a small cut then the motor will stop and the circuit breaker pops and then it wo n't start up again for 20 minutes . If you try chipping pine with needles attached , it does absolutely nothing with the needles - they come out totally whole , not shredded one bit.Chipping short branches is also very difficult . Instead of feeding them , the unit will just bounce them up and down back and forth and then eventually they jam and you have to take the unit apart.Opening the cover to clear those frequent jams is a CHORE . You have to turn a tiny little wheel that 's tucked into the back of the machine for what seems like forever and then pry the cover open . The design is terrible ; someone with arthritis would not be able to accomplish this task even once.The little feeder piece that you 're supposed to use to push the leaves or green matter through is complete junk . The first time I had to put any force on it , the top of it split wide open ; it 's cheaply made.All in all , I think 1 star is 1 too many . Not only does the unit not perform well , the manufacturer seems to be trying everything they can to weasel out of honoring their warranty . ***Update -- just before we hit the 30 day mark , I received my replacement . While I 'm very disappointed in the length of time it took to get me a working unit , I must say that the replacement is like a completely different machine . It does n't jam constantly , it does n't vibrate , the motor seems like a completely different motor - at least twice as strong as the original I received and has only jammed once in 3 days of use vs. every 10 minutes . This new machine is working quite well for my needs maintaining a 1 acre yard with lots of trees . It does excellent work on my smaller limbs , rose trimmings , and even shreds up the garden weeds . You do need to alternate between hard wood and greens or it will get `` stuffed up '' . ******2nd update : Blades are worn out . Totally worn out . Try finding a replacement . Absolutely nothing available on Amazon ; I guess this was designed as a throw away item . What a disappointment***

WELL YOU HAVE TO WORK TEN TIMES BACK AND FORWORD TO GET RID OF WEEDS . Weed killer is better . Sorry it looks attractive but you need a lot of energy to kill your weeds . May be it is good to scratch your lawn for seeding .

As we move away from rat bat poison feeding stations ( to save wildlife that eats the dead rats and then dies because of the poison in them , and to prevent rats from dying in your walls and stinking to high heaven ) this is an option I considered . Well , let me tell you , this thing did catch a rat quickly but I frankly do n't even want to type what I found the next day when I found the rat on this glue pad . It was something out of a horror movie and I felt so bad that I inflicted that kind of suffering on any creature , even a rat ( and I HATE HATE HATE RATS ! ! ! HATE ! ! ! ) .So , I 'm switching back to snap traps , which kill the rats instantly ( in most cases ) . Sorry , I ca n't recommend these .

I would love to build one life-size and stick the inventor on one of these things . Any animal , target species or not , will die a slow , cruel death , often breaking every bone in its body trying to free itself from this monstrous device . When used outdoors owls have gotten trapped in those damn things when they tried to grab a perceived easy prey item.We are trying hard to get these horrible traps banned from markets , so please help spread the word . You would not want your kids or pets to get stuck on these things , so why would any decent human being want to torture wildlife ? There are more humane methods to kill rats , this is absolutely , most definitely , the worst possible choice !

This review is from : iPower GLFANXBOOSTER6 Inline Ducting Booster Fan with Cord , 6 inch ( Lawn & Patio ) Customer review from the Amazon Vine Program ( What 's this ? ) This booster fan has limitations that make it a great solution only under certain circumstances.1 ) This must be the primary fan because it otherwise slows air too much when not powered up and running.2 ) This fan moves air very well . The other side of that benefit is the noise . It will be a constant noise , although that can be mitigated through the use of inexpensive insulation.3 ) There are no speeds . It 's on or it 's off.4 ) The pricing is more than fair . That makes it tempting to use this in other than the precise circumstances it requires .

This is a huge bag of the repellent . Sadly , this is also a product that 's been discontinued for the reason that it most likely does n't work . After following instructions and spreading the repellent over 4 days in different parts of the yard , I have not been able to spot any difference . I switched to Tomcat 34532 Mole and Gopher Liquid Repellent , 32-Ounce and was able to drive the mole ( s ) elsewhere .

I had really hoped this product would get rid of the mole ( s ) or gopher ( s ) that have built tunnels in and under my vegetable garden . This is the first year I 've had to deal with these rodents possibly because of all the wet weather we have experienced this year creating very soft ground for the pests to play in.If I understand this product correctly it 's not poison and will not harm moles or gophers . The moles and gophers are supposedly repelled by the scent this leaves behind . Whatever it 's supposed to do , it 's not doing it . I 'm seeing more and more tunnels every day . Application is easy , I 'll give it an extra star for that , it just does n't work .

I 'm not sure that this is the most effective way to deal with moles in the yard . It is just a repellent so it 's used to repel moles not to kill them or eliminate them . For me , the application process is quite lengthy and time-consuming for just a repellent . You have to apply daily to different areas of the lawn for 4 days in a process of trying to get the moles to move away from your lawn . Each day the process takes watering 20 minutes at a time . I think it an time-consuming process for something that is just an iffy solution from a product that has been discontinued by the manufacturer .
Would not use and will not repurchase . Inhumane product , promotes lengthy death .
I 'd rather chase the varmints away than kill them , but this is n't the product that works , not for me anyway . I guess that 's why it 's been discontinued .

There has been relatively significant traffic of moles under the soil in my yard . I have tried a wide variety of repellants , traps , and poisons for moles , but not all of them have worked , but this one did not work well . I spread them over the mounds where moles were most active , but still this product was ineffective in decreasing the mole activity .

Applied as directed , it was easy to apply , but unfortunately have n't seen much difference in gopher activity . They are persistent ! I was hoping this would work . Also , this seems to have been discontinued by the manufacturer ...
This repellent does n't seem to work at all . We 'd recommend using spikes instead because this product did nothing to keep them out of our yard .

I was sent another mole product and I hoped this one might work better.I used it as instructed and spread it around my first yard where there are two to four active moles tunnels running paying particular attention to the areas nearest my flowerbeds that I spent thousands of dollars to build over the years . The moles have been venturing into the flowerbeds and causing damage so I was hoping to prevent them from coming into them in the first place.I applied this product once but it rained less than 24 hours after that . So when the mole activity seemed more intense a few days later I reapplied it this time only around the flowerbeds in a more concentrated form.The activity seems to be less but I ca n't be sure this product is the reason . If it is , it might be because of the increased concentration I used but that was n't as directed and it should have have required as much to work if the product performed as promised .
I think the spike trap method works a lot better than this one . I do n't like hurting moles though since they are good for the environment if not our lawns and gardens . No positive effects noted .

Tomcat Mole & Gopher Repellent is a spray application that is to be used with your garden hose . The active ingredient is castor oil . Castor oil mixes with water to penetrate the soil . You can use it immediately after seeing the presence of moles or as a preventative treatment.The application is easy to use but I 'm not sure that this is the most effective way to deal with moles in the yard . It is just a repellent so it 's used to repel moles not to kill them or eliminate them . I think it depends on what type of solution you are looking for . For me , if you repel them , they are just going to move to a new spot in the yard.The bottle will cover an area of 100 ' x 100 ' area . It also is necessary to apply again if heavy rainfall falls right after application . It may be necessary to purchase quite a bit of product depending on the size of the area that you are having the mole trouble . I think it an expensive iffy solution from a product that has been discontinued by the manufacturer .

One side of my house is a favorite gathering place for burrowing animals . I hooked up this smelly gunk to a hose and every day I sprayed the entire area of the house where the holes are located until the container was empty . The result ? More holes . It is easy to understand why the manufacturer discontinued this product . The only thing it provides is a stinky odor . The forecast is for thunderstorms which will take care of the odor . Win some , lose some . This one is a loser .

I had the chance to try this out and I ca n't rate the product itself much , all I can rate is the bottle sprayer part because that failed me . I hooked up my garden hose to the bottle as directed and tried using it and it did n't spray as you would have thought . Upon closer inspection it looks like the nozzle part actually has a crack in it which pretty much rendered this useless . I do n't know if it came from the company damaged or was damaged in shipping but in my case this was not useful at all due to poor/cheap design of the sprayer which failed .

Did not work . We have a groundhog that lives under our deck . He is very active and comes in and out through a hole in a corner of the desk . He has a back door hole another 100 feet away . I followed the instructions and provided a heavy application , especially around ( and in ) the two holes . 12 hours later , the groundhog was happily going in and out of the same two holes . I actually hooked this up to the hose while he was out sunning himself on the lawn . I sprayed him directly . He did n't seem to care and went back to chomping the grass in the same spot I sprayed.At the end of my application , there was still a bit of product left in the bottle . So , I dumped it fully concentrated down the hole . No effect whatsoever.The listing says it was discontinued . I 'm not sure sure why , specifically . But this does not work on my groundhog .
I had hopes for it , being the type of guy that would rather chase the critters away than kill them . But after several tries , I had no success .

There has been relatively significant traffic of moles under the soil in my yard . I have tried a wide variety of repellants , traps , and poisons for moles , but not all of them have worked , but this one did not work well . I am not sure if the product was too diluted or it simply did not work . If this product is good , then why is it that the manufacturer discontinued this product ?

Using this has been a challenge given the time constraints of the Vine Program I received it through -- it has been a very rainy month but I did manage to use it once . After I 've used it again I 'll come back and update this review IF the results are different but I 'm not hopeful.I followed the directions on the product and sprayed this over the first two flowerbeds that have been wrecked by mole tunnels . Three days later there are new even larger tunnels in the beds as though this spray attracted them ! The only positive is that this did not damage the plants and flowers in any way , they look as good as ever , and the number of butterflies and bees seems steady .

All excitement about this fire pit went out the window as soon as I placed the base of the fire pit on the ground . As many other reviewers have mentioned , this fire pit is extremely wobbly and does not rest flush against the ground , which drove me absolutely crazy as I tried figuring out whether or not my brick patio was uneven . I even went and grabbed a level to make sure of it , and after getting positive confirmation , I knew with certainty that this fire pit is uneven , which is an absolute shame because the pictures make it look extremely stylish . As for the other parts , you can tell they are of relatively low quality , and nothing at all really seems to fit just right on this fire pit . There are better options out there , especially considering the price , so take a pass on this poorly made offering .

This is over $ 200 and I 'd say it 's worth , maybe $ 49 to $ 79 . Even then , I 'd look for a better product in any price range . It was easy enough to put together , even for me , but when I put it on it 's feet it was so not substantial . It reminds me of these super cheap bar stools we got once ... no one ever sat in them because they just felt cheap and wobbly.When I read that I could not use this on my deck , I was even more disappointed . You have to drag it out into the yard to use it , where I already have a nice , sturdy , rock fire pit . In the grass it was a little less tippy , but all-in-all I 'd pass on this one . I had one fire in it and kept the hose very close-by in case it just crashed to the ground . I am going to let it air out a bit and use it on my deck , filling it with flowers .

When looking at this product I see something sleek and modern with appealing aesthetics , but beyond that there is nothing I can find that would make this product worth getting . When making the decision on a fire pit quality of the materials used should be a deciding factor , this could make a big difference in how long the pit lasts . There were quite a few pieces for assembly and once they were all together the pit was unstable and rocked back and forth like the legs were uneven , something that can not possibly be safe , and the bowl is thin which also seems unsafe . The only way I can see this thing lasting longer than a few months is for someone to build a paver wall around it ( for stability ) and to NEVER move it because this stand/base seems like it would n't last more than a few moves around the patio .

Well , I 'm setting here wondering what positive to say on this item . Its poorly built , flimsy and reeks of the words `` fire hazard . '' The way it is put together is easy enough , unfortunately in all the wrong ways . That 's terribly disappointing , too , because I had high hopes for this item , imagining myself enjoying it while taking to the summer - when it finally comes . The cost , to me at least , seems astounding , considering how flimsy the build on it is . Really , the wind moves it around outside , causing it to shift back and forth every few minutes.It looks cool anyhow ; and considering that 's all I can do with it and feel safe , I guess that 's a mild something .

This product is designed to capture tiny mice . Mice around where i am are not giant , but not tiny mice . I guess your average mouse is not tiny . It can catch an average sized mouse , but the noise and movement of the mouse inside stops any other mouse from being caught . And it is not big enough to catch large mice ( not rats which is definitely not possible )

Over this winter I 've been getting small field mice in my garage looking for a warm place to stay . I 've been placing several plastic classic-type ( trigger snaps a lid closed on mouse ) traps that have worked very well . When I was offered this I was excited to try one that could collect multiple mice . I am very disappointed.It 's unclear how this even works to trap the mice ( I guess I 'll find out if it ever works ) as it sits on the floor and the underneath is hollow . I placed this in the same space as the plastic traps and the plastic traps are still collecting mice and this one sits unused.I 'll update this if I ever catch a mouse with this . Until then I 'll stick with the classic snap closed type of traps.UPDATE : after nearly a week in the garden shed where I know mice are active at times I still have n't caught anything .

The Victor tri-kill mouse trap is an interesting pest control product . It is very easy to use and set . There is no chance of accidental injury . Baiting it was no problem . I was a little worried about how light it was.I baited the trap with peanut butter and set it . I placed in an area where we have tons of mice come in from the field . In that same area I have a bunch of traditional cheap sticky traps . I checked this trap for two weeks . I have often found it moved slightly from where I left it . But I have never found a mouse in it . The sticky traps in the same area are catching tons of mice . I can only conclude that this is not a great trap.There are some real pros to this design . Perhaps Victor can revisit it and make it a little more effective .

The Victor Tri-Kill Mouse Trap is a good idea in theory but in practice a trap to catch a single mouse is better . This trap does not have separate sealed chambers but is more like a roofed room with three doors and no floor or interior walls . It does not have a strong metal spring to instantly kill the mice but a bar that catches and strangles them while leaving them exposed . I would prefer a single trap to catch & release the mice or if necessary , one that would kill them instantly and humanely over this method .

You have to feel back for the lonely inventor , ever striving to make a better mousetrap . The design of this trap is creative , it 's a snare ( basically a plastic noose ) . However , in our tests in an old house , traditional snap traps continue to catch mice , and this one has n't .

While this is a good looking trap , I ca n't say that it did much . I had it set up for a couple of weeks in my mother-in-laws house because she said she saw a mouse in her house . Well , I put three snap traps down , and the second night one snapped , and the following night another snapped . All were baited with peanut butter ( the same brand ) . I can say that this is much safer than the snap traps , having almost snapped my fingers more than once . Other than that , there is n't much to say . I think it is an expensive product that does not do what it is supposed to do , at least for me . Out of all the traps I have used , the snap traps have been great.I also have an electric trap that is amazing , but it was VERY expensive becuase it will kill a large rat ! So far , for me , nothing beats a snap trap ... .just watch your fingers . Of course , I do not have pets , and I do n't put them where my kids can get at them . If this would have caught ANYTHING , I might have given it a better rating , but as it stands , I can not . I will keep it baited ( with fresh peanut better ) and I will report back if things change , but I 'm not holding my breath .

I have set thousands of mouse traps over the years , and am a firm believer that the `` traditional model '' has proved itself as a tried and true tool . I have no problems looking into alternatives , however , and have had fun over the years catching mice of different species in everything from Sherman traps to a neat PETA- sponsored live trap ( worked great ) .This trap , the Victor Tri-kill Moue Trap , is headed for the trash . It 's not that it ca n't catch a mouse . It can . After the first mouse , the trap is jerked around and moved away from its original placement . Since mice are very neophobic , best success is for traps to be set right next to baseboards or known traveling lanes . So I do n't like that the trap moves from where I want it to be . Second , the spring is just weak . A traditional snap trap kills by causing extreme damage to a mouse , hopefully on the head and neck . This trap seems to ... strangle mice ? Are n't we past this level of revenge ? Finally , the trap is not robust in its construction . One of the panels fell off as I was resetting it ! A traditional snap trap is a much better , predictable , and reliable purchase .

The idea behind this mouse trap is impressive -- make three entryways for the mice so that even if they scurry past one side of it , they 'll be suckered in by the smell wafting through the door on the other side . Well ... that did n't happen , despite having this set up in my garage for the past few weeks . I know there are mice in there because I can hear them . They must be laughing together over a few beers at the Hole in the Wall Bar at how ridiculous this baiter is.The trap itself is pretty much a no-brainer . You paste your peanut butter onto the plate , make sure all the doors are shut tight , and put it near a spot mice frequent ( like right outside that Hole in the Wall Bar ) . If you think the bait has gotten a bit old , you can just wash it out under the faucet and paste some new stuff on.One plus on this trap is that the springs are all inside the trap , so it seems safe enough to leave around pets . Another plus is that there are no chemicals involved , and it definitely looks like it will kill quickly . Our mice seem to be smarter than the average critters , so perhaps we should just swap out the peanut butter for a smear of Guinness froth and catch some leprechauns instead.There is a 30 day warranty with this thing , and you 're supposed to see the most mice caught on day 1 , so even if this trap disappoints you as much as it did me , you can still get your money back .

After over a year , I have n't caught a single mouse , however in the same time I 've caught about five mice with conventional snap-traps . The bait was n't even touched ! My hypothesis is that they ca n't smell the bait or are too timid to poke their head into the noose part of the trap.I even had the tri-kill out with NO snap traps for a good month , during that time there was clear evidence of mice , so I finally re-deployed the snap traps after which I caught two mice in quick succession.Sorry , but 2 stars until it catches somebody.Original review below ... Here in Michigan the local field mice come into your garage every winter and eat up your grass seed and anything that 's even slightly edible.The end of fall / start of winter is the peak where I can fill 2-3 mouse traps every other day . I tried a `` Nooski '' trap recently but was n't entirely impressed . It was less prone to accidental release , but was moer tricky to set.This is almost foolproof - you press the three arrows down and it 's set . When it 's tripped the arrow pops back up.One concern I have is that this has an internal bar which comes up to grab and kill the mouse . My experience is that in cold weather the mouse can `` Freeze '' to the bar on a conventional trap making it hard to clear . This strikes me as being worse since it 's a fairly narrow loop.Since it 's the end of winter , no mice caught yet . My neighbor has also been letting his cat roam so that 's probably been a factor . Will update later ... .

This grill is new for 2013 and it was very easy to assemble . All the parts were in the box and there was n't any damage . I cooked chicken and steak on it the first night and it worked Okay . I bought a aftermarket grill 2 years ago and it leaked grease all over my deck plus it did n't cook evenly and had hot and cold spots so I went back to a Weber because we could afford it this year . My last Weber lasted 10 years and I ca n't imagine why this one would n't do the same . The Stainless is heavy duty and I like that the propane tank is hidden behind the door and out of site . The small foot print is a plus but not the reason I bought the grill it 's simply because there are only two of use now and serves our purpose . Update 5/18/13 I have cooked several times and the grill is not heating very well . The cross over tube flame is red not blue and cooking times have decreased . I called Weber and there going to send a new burner and we will see if it solved the problem . I will update when I replace the parts . Update 5/26/2013 I have installed the new burner tubes and had a party this weekend and it took over one hour to cook thin burgers . This is the worst grill I have ever owned . Weber is sending a rep to see if it can be fixed but at this point I just want them to do the right thing and take it back before the summer is over . Update 5/28/2013 Lowe 's has a 90 day return policy so I took it back and ordered a Genesis S-310 three burner with 38,000 BTU . I have to wait two weeks for the order so I hope it 's worth it .

This is my second Weber purchase ( Genesis was the first ) . Based on the Consumer Reports review I purchased this blindly . It is a low end version of the Genesis . The major bummer was that it came with dents in just about every part of the grill . It was especially bad in the hood where it was very visible . I wished I had purchased it locally so that I could return it . After the grill was out of the box and spread out on my deck the `` genie was out of the bottle '' and I put it together.Lastly , it is smaller than most three burner grills . With a family of 5 and the need to grill pizza , it has a small surface size that we could have worked with but not the size I expected.It was very easy to put together if you are worried about that . It took about 2 hours.My last review , I gave my Genesis 5 stars ... Would definitely not buy Spirit again .

I like the way new Weber kettle grills cook . Unfortunately , the long term durability is poor . The grates are cheap , the porcelin finish on both my grills was flawed and cracked , and corrosion and rust take this grill to the curbside prematurely.. For the money , you are better off to buy a $ 50 Charbroil grill . I live on the coast and my Webers rusted straight away . I bought a Stok grill for less than the cost of the TOL Weber and so far , no rust or corrosion ... ..plus I have cast Iron grates instead of the caot hanger style grates that come with the Weber . The Stok also comes with other handy accessories like a charcoal starter that lets you avoid charcoal lighter fluid entirely.Follow up : My Weber grills took a beating due to inadequate packaging systems . This likely contributed to damage of the handle attachment points and the corrosion that was able to exploit the damaged areas . The marine environment I live in can be harsh on any metal that is not protected .

This product sounded like a great idea to me . Be prepared that it is cheaply made enamel finished metal with sharp edges . It is so small that you wo n't be able to smoke a decent sized piece of meat . You may be able to do a couple of chicken breasts or pork chops , but that 's about it . There is a grate that fits over the basket , which would allow you to cook a somewhat larger piece of meat , but it does n't fit unless you keep the basket inside , which cramps the wood chips . This is contrary to the instruction manual , which really does n't give many instructions . It just shows diagrams of the cooker . It would be nice to have a few recipes of cooking suggestions . This item is definitely not up to Charbroil 's normal standards .

Nice pan but its so small that its useless for anything but to throw some veggies in . For a family of four like ours , that 's really even pushing it.I was so disappointed with this because I was really looking forward to using it . It would be great if it was just bigger .

This device is nothing more than a pan and is not something I would use often . I had Charbroil 's Inferred grill and that was a big mistake . This continues the mistake on a Weber . Inferred to Charbroil is nothing but a pan between the flames to eliminate the flame . Wow , now there is a concept . It is all hype as far as I am concerned and not too useful . Use a low priced pyrex roaster or a low metal pan and you will get the same thing for much less and probably much easier to clean and store . This probably wo n't burn through as fast as the Charbroil grill . I was skeptical and my fears were confirmed . Sorry , I find it a dumb product which is not needed . It is in the garage already . Like the Beatles sang `` I should have known better '' .

I looked forward to receiving this item but my hopes were pretty much dashed when I opened the box.First of all , it is very cheaply made with rough metal edges . I did n't find any that were sharp enough to cut me but the potential is there . What is with the lid not having a handle of any kind ? Be prepared to use a spatula or fork to clumisly remove the lid when you want to check your food . As far as I 'm concerned that is a big omission.Inside the unit , do n't expect to cook large volumes . The inside is big enough for one steak or two petite cuts . Two or three chicken breasts will fill this one to capacity . If you 're thinking of smoking a small roast , it better be pretty small . A boneless pork loin might fit but most likely you will need to cut off one end or cut it in half.Charbroil does include some wood chips with the infusion cooker so you wo n't need to run out to buy some to try this out . Following directions and putting them in the proper place it seemed I needed to heat my grill to a temperature higher than I normally use . Plus getting 4 big burners going to cook with this unit is quite a drain on the propane vs. the achieved results.My test food was a thick , stuffed pork chop which barely fit in the cooking chamber . Keeping all four burners going at about 3/4 capacity I was able to achieve a good tastiing meal . There was some smoke flavor but not near as much as if I were to use either my electric smoker or scatter wood chips above the burners . it did however seem to keep the pork chop moister than if cooked directly on the grill for a longer period of time ( infusion ? ) .In conclusion , I 'll keep this around and perhaps use it every now and then when grilling just for myself but it is far from being my favorite tool to use on the grill . It is hampered by being cheaply made , inconvenient to use ( no handle on lid for example ) , a marginal design and small interior space .
